div.l: Thise clerkes bet him wel and leet him lie
And greten hem / and took here hors anoon
And eek here mele and on here wey þei goon
And atte Mille yett þei took here cake
Of half a busshel flour͗e ful wel I bake
Thus is þe proude Miller wel I bete
And haþ I lost þe grinding of þe whete
And paide for þe soper eueridel
Of Aleyn and of Iohn þat bette him wele
His wif is swyued and his dought̉er als
Lo swiche it is a Meller to be fals
And þerfore þis prouerbe is seide ful soth
Him þar not wene wel þat evel doth
A giler shal himsilf begiled be
And god þat sitteþ high in mageste
Saue alle þis companye grete and smale
Thus haue I quyt þe Meller in my tale
HEre begynneth the prolog of þe Cokes tale
The cook of London whil þe Reue spak
For Ioie him þought he clowed hīm on þe bak
Ha ha · qduod he for cristꝭes passion
This Meller̉e haþ a sharp conclusion
Vpon his argument of herbigage
Wel saide salamon in his language
Ne bringe not euery man in to þin hous
For herboring be night is ꝑperilous
Wel ought aman auysed for to be
Whom þat he brought in to his pⁱriuete
I praie to god so yeue me sorowe and care
Iff eủere sithen I hight hogge of ware
Herde I meller bettere I sette awerke
He hadde a Iape of malice in þe derke
And þerfore if ye vouche saf to her
